All this talk about Mars and no one mentions the blindingly obvious next step in reviving this dead planet. It needs shielding from solar wind, a.k.a. a magnetosphere. This means it needs stronger gravitational pull onto it from its satellites, which are currently tiny Phobos and Deimos. We can increase Mars' magnetosphere by adding more satellites to it, or somehow increasing the gravitational pull of its current satellites. Here's a simple equation to show how it works. We currently see this relationship with Juptier's satellites, although it's the other way around because Jupiter's gravity is warming the cores of its satellites and in Mars' case we need to warm Mars by adding more gravitational pull to it. In layman's terms, satellites = gravitational pull = tectonic plate pull = friction = heat = liquid core = magnetosphere = protection from solar wind and an atmosphere will not get blown away. Many stones fall back on Mars after this event, created the gigantic deserts filled with rocks, the two biggest stones remained in its orbit as its moons, Phobos and Deimos, part of a crippled, completely devastated planet, and other stones were simply thrown in space in all directions, which is why we can find meteorites from Mars here on Earth.

Why do some many astronomy commentators make such extravagant assumptions about the longevity of humanity in the cosmic scale.
Vertebrate species or genera don't last more than a couple million years. Any descendant of humans in 100myr will be nothing like us. Even if by some amazing stagnation of evolution we remained similar on structure like crocodiles or sharks we still wouldnt be Homo sapiens or Homo at all, in the same way fossil species of "living fossils" aren't really a so close a match of their ancient ancestors as the untrained eye might think.
There is no way of predicting what life might be like in a billion years, but it will most definitvely be; not us.

Circe's gravity attracts Phobos and Deimos and will eventually add to its mass. Planetary engineering techniques are being used to gently allow Phobos and Deimos to land on Circe. By 2304, Circe, now a moon of Mars, has two sub moons of its own, Phobos and Deimos that will land on Circe.

"Land" is too modest a term, as the crash will be substantial, but will not annihilate Circe or raise any lasting debris. The two martian moons will become mountains on the surface of Circe, where it is agreed the two moons will no longer be listed as moons but mountains on the surface of Circe. QUICK CORRECTION: We said in the video that Jupiters gravity probably "pushed" the asteroids out of the Asteroid Belt. The wording was pretty bad and lots of you got confused. What we meant was that Jupiters huge gravity interfered with the orbit of the asteroid belt and consequently slingshot some asteroids out of it. And by chance Mars was at the right place on the right time to "catch" them (meaning they couldn't escape Mars' gravity and started to orbit it). Gravity can't "push" something like we animated it in the video – sorry we didn't make this clear enough!

Q: How many Moons does Mars have?
A: Zero; Mars has two natural satellites, neither of which are named 'Moon'.

Yes, I know it is acceptable to call other planets' satellites 'Moons' but I don't think it should be. If we can call all the other natural satellites 'Moon' then I think we should come up with an original name for our natural satellite. Of course, the real solution is not to rename our natural satellite but to stop referring to all the other satellites in the solar system as 'Moons'.
